```{r}
statedata = as.data.frame(state.x77)
colnames(statedata) = c('popu', 'inc', 'illit', 'life.exp', 'murder',
                        'hs.grad', 'frost', 'area')

plot(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata)
cor(statedata[, 'life.exp'], statedata[, 'inc'])

plot(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata, type = 'n')
text(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata, state.abb)

model1 = lm(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata)
model1

plot(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata, xlab = 'Income',
     ylab = 'Life Expectancy')
abline(model1)

par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
for(i in 1:4) {
  ## Plot the population
  plot(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata, xlab = 'Income',
       ylab = 'Life Expectancy', main = paste('Random sample', format(i)),
       ylim = c(min(life.exp), max(life.exp) + 0.3))
  
  abline(model1)
  
  if(i == 1) {
    legend(3030, 74.2, pch = c(NA, NA, NA, 1, 16), lty = c(1, 1, 2, NA, NA),
           col = c(1, 2, 2, 1, 2), cex = 0.7, bty = 'n',
           c('population truth', 'sample estimate', 'sample confidence band',
             'states', 'sampled'))
  }
  
  ## Select the sample
  selected.states = sample(1:50, 10)
  points(statedata[selected.states, 'inc'],
         statedata[selected.states, 'life.exp'], pch = 16, col = 2)
  
  ## Fit a regression line using the sample
  model.se1 = lm(life.exp ~ inc, data = statedata[selected.states, ])
  abline(model.se1, col = 2)
  
  # Make a confidence band
  
  ## Calculate the width of the band
  WW = sqrt(2 * qf(0.95, 2, nrow(statedata) - 2))
  
  ## Generate plotting x values
  plot.x = data.frame(inc = seq(3000, 7000, 1))
  
  ## The standard error of the fitted values
  plot.fit = predict(model.se1, plot.x, level = 0.95, interval = 'confidence',
                     se.fit = T)
  lines(plot.x$inc, plot.fit$fit[, 1] + WW * plot.fit$se.fit, col = 2, lty = 2)
  lines(plot.x$inc, plot.fit$fit[, 1] - WW * plot.fit$se.fit, col = 2, lty = 2)
}
```
